Canine parvovirus infection (also called "parvo") is a highly contagious gastrointestinal disease with a high mortality rate. [[1]](#_note-1) X Research source [ The virus is common in puppies. Experienced dog owners and breeders often panic when they suspect one of their dogs has parvo; they know how quickly the condition advances and how lethal it can be. If your dog has parvo, getting to a veterinarian quickly can increase the odds of survival. Your vet will be able to tell you whether you're dealing with parvo or another canine disease like bacterial hemorrhagic enteritis, coccidiosis, or hookworm infestation. ](#) Steps Recognizing the Symptoms of Parvo - 1Monitor your dog's behavior. In general, the first sign of a parvo infection is lethargy. Your dog may become less active, eventually retreating to a corner and staying put. [[2]](#_note-2)X [Expert Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience) [Ray Spragley, DVM](/Author/Ray-Spragley-DVM)Expert Interview. 19 February 2021. You might also notice that they don't have much of an appetite or they start to seem weaker than normal. Veterinarian [[3]](#_note-3)X Research source - Parvo usually progresses quickly—lethargy is often quickly followed by vomiting and diarrhea. - 2Watch for fever. Dogs with parvo usually develop a high fever. Signs of fever might include warm ears or a warm nose and red eyes. [[4]](#_note-4)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. [Go to source](#)You can also use a rectal thermometer or an ear thermometer to take your dog's temperature—if it's higher than around 101-102.5 °F (38.3-39.2 °C), they have a fever. [[5]](#_note-5)X Research source Advertisement - Any change in temperature can be a sign—some dogs will have a lower-than-normal body temperature, instead. [[6]](#_note-6)X Research source - Any change in temperature can be a sign—some dogs will have a lower-than-normal body temperature, instead. - 3Pay attention to vomiting. Parvo attacks the rapidly dividing cells that line the stomach and intestines. This causes your dog's stomach to become irritated and ulcerated, which leads to severe vomiting. [[7]](#_note-7)X Research source Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience) [Ray Spragley, DVM](/Author/Ray-Spragley-DVM)Expert February 2021. Veterinarian - Since your dog can't hold down food or water, they can quickly become severely dehydrated and malnourished, which can lead to shock or even death. - 4Pay attention to your dog's stools. Typically the diarrhea associated with parvo is particularly severe. Some people say that it has a unique smell that's different than your dog's normal stools. [[9]](#_note-9)X Research source Interview. 19 February 2021. If you see this, take your dog to the vet right away. Veterinarian [[11]](#_note-11)X Research source - 5Check for signs of anemia. Parvo causes gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to anemia. To see if your dog might be anemic, press down on the gums. A healthy dog's gums will quickly return to their normal color, usually within two seconds; if it takes longer, your dog may be anemic. Anemia may also lead to a noticeable paleness of the gums. [[12]](#_note-12)X Research source - 6Be especially mindful of parvo if you have a puppy. Although it can affect older dogs, parvo most commonly occurs in puppies between 6 and 20 weeks of age. Parvo is especially serious in puppies because their immune system hasn't fully developed yet. In addition, vaccination may not be fully effective until your puppy is between 14 and 16 weeks old because antibodies in their mother's milk may interfere with the vaccine. [[13]](#_note-13)X Research source - It can be hard to spot the early signs of parvo in a puppy, which unfortunately means the mortality rate can be high for younger dogs. Pay close attention to any changes in their behavior and take them in to the vet if you think anything's amiss. [[14]](#_note-14)X [Expert Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience) [Ray Spragley, DVM](/Author/Ray-Spragley-DVM)Expert Interview. 19 February 2021. Veterinarian - It can be hard to spot the early signs of parvo in a puppy, which unfortunately means the mortality rate can be high for younger dogs. Pay close attention to any changes in their behavior and take them in to the vet if you think anything's amiss. Diagnosing Parvo - 1Take your dog to a veterinarian immediately. Unfortunately, parvo is fast acting—it can be fatal in just 48-72 hours after the first symptoms appear. If you can get your dog to the vet quickly, though, they'll have a much better chance of recovery. [[15]](#_note-15)X Research source - 2Ask your vet to do an ELISA test. To diagnose parvo, your veterinarian may perform the Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay (ELISA) test. This test checks your dog's stool for evidence of parvo. It can be done in your veterinarian's office, and the results will come back in about 15 minutes. [[16]](#_note-16)X Research source - The ELISA test gives rapid results, but sometimes false positives do occur, so your vet may recommend further testing, like taking a white blood cell count or sending a sample to a lab. - On the other hand, more testing to confirm parvo may not really be necessary. The parvovirus causes severe illness. Since the condition is managed with supportive care rather than cured, it is not always necessary to run diagnostic tests. - 3Get a white blood count for confirmation. Since an ELISA test sometimes comes back with a false positive, your vet may also check your dog's white blood cell count. Parvo attacks a dog's bone marrow, so a low white blood cell count is usually a pretty good indicator that the dog has parvo—especially in combination with a positive ELISA test. [[17]](#_note-17)X Research source - 4Wait for lab results if your vet does a PCR test. In a PCR test, your vet will send a fecal sample from your dog to a lab for testing. The results of this will confirm whether your dog has parvo. [[18]](#_note-18)X Research source - This takes longer than an ELISA test, but the results are more accurate. - 5Follow your veterinarian's suggestions for treatment. There is no cure for the parvovirus; however, your veterinarian can recommend supportive therapies and practical measures that will increase your dog's odds of survival. These might include: [[19]](#_note-19)X Research source - Hospitalization - Anti-vomiting medication - Anti-diarrheals - Intravenous fluids Expert Q&A [Add New Question] - QuestionCan older dogs get parvo?Yes, but it's pretty rare and unlikely, especially if they've been vaccinated. You almost always see parvo in puppies between 6 weeks and 6 months of age. - QuestionWhat does parvo poop look like?A dog with parvo is going to have severe diarrhea, and it should be immediately obvious that your dog isn't defecating normally. There's also going to be blood in their stool. - QuestionHow can I treat my dog at home for parvo?You can't. If you suspect your dog has parvo, you need to take them to a vet immediately. [See more answers](/Questions/Tell-if-Your-Dog-Has-Parvo#offset=3) [Submit] Tips - Vaccination is the only way to prevent your puppy from getting parvo. The first shot can be done as early as five to six weeks of age; it needs to be repeated every two to three weeks for a total of at least three shots. [[20]](#_note-20)X Research sourceThanks - Parvo is more likely including Rottweilers, American Pitbull Terriers, Doberman Pinschers, and German Shepherds. If your dog belongs to one of these groups, be particularly vigilant in watching for parvo. [[21]](#_note-21)X Research sourceThanks - Parvo is a very stable, persistent virus. It is resistant to a number of disinfectants, and it can survive for long periods—up to several months, even. It is important to maintain good sanitation and disinfection in your dog's premises. Look for products that are labeled as effective in disinfecting against parvo, or, on bleach-safe items, use a solution of 1 part bleach to 30 parts water.Thanks [Show More Tips](#) Warnings - Do not attempt to treat parvo on your own. Even when dogs receive high-quality veterinary care, the virus can be fatal; trying to treat it on your own is much too risky.Thanks - If you have multiple dogs, isolate your sick dog immediately and keep your other dogs out of the contaminated area. Parvo can be spread by the infected dog's feces, so you'll need to disinfect the area thoroughly before it's safe for your other animals. You'll also want to watch for symptoms such as bloody diarrhea and vomiting. When you notice these symptoms, take your dog's temperature, since Parvo usually causes a high fever between 104 to 106° F. If your dog has a fever, take it to the vet immediately so they can run tests and start treatment as soon as possible.
